Introducing qubit phase
=======================

| Now that we have seen how to make :math:`|0\rangle`, :math:`|1\rangle`,
  and superposition states, let’s investigate how we can change the
  phase of the superposition. We have added the following gates: :math:`Z`,
  :math:`S`, :math:`S^{\dagger}`, :math:`T`, and :math:`T^{\dagger}`.

|image0|

| The *:math:`Z`* gate is a :math:`\pi` rotation around the Z axis, the :math:`S`
  gate is a rotation of :math:`\pi/2` around Z, and the :math:`T` gate is a
  :math:`\pi/4` rotation around Z. :math:`S^{\dagger}` is the inverse of :math:`S`
  (does a :math:`-\pi/2` around Z; :math:`SS^{\dagger}` returns the original
  state), and :math:`T^{\dagger}` is the inverse of :math:`T`. These rotations
  give the qubit a component along the Y direction of the Bloch sphere,
  which is a representation of the complex information in the qubit
  state.

When the qubit is in the \|0> state, Z doesn’t do much. But when the
qubit is in the :math:`|+\rangle` state, you can see that Z flips the
state from :math:`|+\rangle` to :math:`|-\rangle`.

|image1|\ 

|
| **Z gate: when qubit is in the |0> state**

.. raw:: html

   <a href="https://quantumexperience.ng.bluemix.net/qx/editor?codeId=95d0c305399b7db58c1c6189b6a333e5&sharedCode=true" target="_parent"><img src="https://dal.objectstorage.open.softlayer.com/v1/AUTH_039c3bf6e6e54d76b8e66152e2f87877/codes/code-95d0c305399b7db58c1c6189b6a333e5.png" style="width: 100%; max-width: 600px;"></a>

| |image3|

| 

|
| **Z gate: when the qubit is in the |+> state**

.. raw:: html

   <a href="https://quantumexperience.ng.bluemix.net/qx/editor?codeId=95d0c305399b7db58c1c6189b6c3e493&sharedCode=true" target="_parent"><img src="https://dal.objectstorage.open.softlayer.com/v1/AUTH_039c3bf6e6e54d76b8e66152e2f87877/codes/code-95d0c305399b7db58c1c6189b6c3e493.png" style="width: 100%; max-width: 600px;"></a>

Let’s now examine intermediate rotations around the Z axis, starting in
the :math:`|+\rangle` superposition state. Below is a summary of how
different rotations around the Z axis impact measurements in the
superposition basis.

|image5|\ 

| 

| |image6|
